Quoting Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...>:
 
> I agree that I would be simulating the highest level
> control task related to steering and power usage.  The
> methods I use, if succesful, could theoretically be
> applied to a real robot, but it would be difficult,
> because a fairly accurate simulation of the entire
> real situation is required in order to perform
> neuroevolution.  Developing this simulation is the
> difficult part.  We cannot perform neuroevolution in
> the actual vehicle, but only in a computer simulation.

By 'high-level' task I meant a NN that would receive at it's inputs 
the bearing and distance of a target location plus information about 
local obstacles. The output of the NN would then be a bearing and 
speed the vehicle should go in in order to get to the target 
location, but avoiding the local obstacles. A model can be built for 
this task and an NN evolved for it.

The resultant NN is then fixed, it's a black box with inputs and 
outputs, no more evolving of the NN is necessary. 

We would then move onto the next task, evolving a NN that receives at 
its inputs a bearing and speed the vehicle should move. It's outputs 
then give controls signals for steering and drive motors.

When both NNs are ready they can be combined to create a complete 
system. Keep in mind this is just an example scenario to explain my 
point, it's not meant to be complete!

The point is that the first 'high'level' black box should not require 
any further evolving in order to work in the real world - it can be 
used as it is. 

The other task though would require complex models - e.g. to take 
into account different surface and terrain types. These sort of 
models can never be completely accurate and this does present a major 
problem for evolving solutions since you need to be able to run many 
trial runs automatically.


Colin.
